notes: SPARK Statements (V2) with age-appropriate examples for 11–15 year-olds. Likert: Strongly Agree → Strongly Disagree.

scale.label: Strongly Agree → Strongly Disagree
scale.value_mapping_note: Map as needed to your scoring system (e.g., SA=5… SD=1).

themes.name: Self-direction (Initiative)
themes.focus: Taking initiative, being proactive, bias toward action

items.text: I am willing to risk failure to reach my goals.
examples: You try out for the school team (or a local club) even if you’re not sure you’ll make it, because you want to improve.

items.text: When I work at something, I care about doing my best.
examples: You rework a design or paragraph until it’s clear and neat, then ask a friend or teacher for one suggestion to improve it.

items.text: I like coming up with new ways to solve problems.
examples: In art you test a different technique to get a texture you want; at home you rearrange your study space to help you focus.

items.text: I take the initiative myself, rather than relying on others
examples: For a group poster, you set up the task list and volunteer to do the first draft without being told, then invite others to add.

items.text: When I set a goal, I immediately start working on it
examples: You decide to learn 10 Spanish verbs a week and spend 10 minutes that evening making the first set of flashcards.

items.text: I make plans that help me accomplish what I aim for.
examples: For a science project or music performance, you break it into mini‑deadlines in your planner and tick them off across the week.

items.text: I expect good things to happen to me.
examples: You enter a school competition believing your effort could lead to a positive outcome, even if you don’t win.

items.text: I am excited about my future.
examples: You look up college courses or careers and enjoy seeing which subjects link to them.

items.text: I trust that my future will turn out well.
examples: After a low test score, you believe that with practice and help from teachers you can improve next time.

items.text: My life will make a difference in the world.
examples: You volunteer for an eco‑club litter pick because you feel your actions matter.

items.text: I am doing things now that will help me to achieve my purpose in life.
examples: You practise coding 15 minutes a day because you think tech might be part of your future.

items.text: I have long term dreams, and I am taking steps to achieve them
examples: If you want to be a nurse, you choose extra science revision sessions and watch short NHS career videos.

themes.name: Awareness (Relationships and Empathy)
themes.focus: Working with others, empathy, fostering relationships

items.text: I feel bad when someone gets their feelings hurt.
examples: You notice a classmate left out at lunch and it bothers you.

items.text: I understand how those close to me feel.
examples: You can tell your friend is stressed before a test and you check in with them.

items.text: It is important to me to understand how other people feel.
examples: During a debate, you restate the other side’s point before sharing your view.

items.text: I am happy when others succeed.
examples: You congratulate a classmate who got a higher grade than you without sarcasm.

items.text: I go out of my way to help others.
examples: You stay behind after club to help tidy equipment that isn’t yours.

items.text: I help others even if it requires a lot of my time.
examples: You spend part of break helping a partner catch up on missed notes, then check they understand before the next lesson.

items.text: I encourage my friends to be the best they can be.
examples: You remind a friend about their art portfolio deadline and offer to look over it with them after school.

items.text: I put in more effort than many of my peers to achieve success.
examples: You complete one extra retrieval quiz at home or practise an extra 15 minutes on a skill when others stop.

items.text: I see tasks through to completion even when I encounter obstacles.
examples: When your slideshow corrupts, you rebuild the key slides instead of giving up.

items.text: People can count on me to get tasks done
examples: If you promise to bring resources for group work, you bring them on time and let people know if anything changes.

items.text: I always do the things that I say I am going to do
examples: You told your teacher you’d attend revision club, so you go—even when you’re tired.

items.text: I persist and find ways to overcome challenges even when tasks become difficult.
examples: Stuck on a tricky equation, you try a different method and ask a classmate before asking the teacher.

items.text: I find creative ways to overcome challenges when things don't go as planned.
examples: If the library is full, you use printed notes and a quiet classroom; if your device dies, you switch to paper and keep going.

items.text: When I face setbacks, I reflect on what went wrong and adjust my approach.
examples: After losing marks for careless errors, you start underlining key words in questions.

items.text: If something interests me, I try to learn more about it.
examples: After a history lesson, you watch a short video about the same topic at home.

items.text: I use the knowledge I gain at school in my life.
examples: You use budgeting from maths to plan saving for a school trip or to manage pocket money.

items.text: Being a student is central to my identity
examples: You keep an organised exercise book and take pride in adding a brief ‘next step’ after feedback.

items.text: I take charge of my own learning.
examples: You set your own practice questions or make flashcards without being told.

items.text: I care about doing well in school
examples: You choose to redo a piece of work to move it from ‘good’ to ‘great’.

items.text: I always pay attention in class
examples: You face the speaker, track key points in your notes, and ask a short clarifying question when something isn’t clear.

items.text: I always come to class well-prepared
examples: You pack your bag the night before—with the right books and any printed sheets—without being reminded by parents or carers.
